results.title: Message from Moree (A) [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Judy Rymer, Bevan Childs, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Rymer Bayly Watson
results.brief_description: Moree, several hours north-west of Sydney, once had the reputation for being New South Wales’ most racist town, particularly during the 1990s. A rich agricultural district of wealthy farmers, Moree also is home to a poverty-stricken mainly unemployed minority Aboriginal community, giving rise to a high crime rate, violence, racism, despair and social disintegration. By 1996 Moree was in crisis with unemployment for Aboriginals at 44% (non-Aboriginals 7%). Dick Estens, a cotton farmer whose passion for the underdog and a refusal to acknowledge or accept failure, set about with a private group of concerned citizens in establishing the AES (Aboriginal Employment Strategy). His mission was to gain employment for Aboriginal people through a process of mentoring and partnerships. This documentary follows the handover by Dick Estens of the leadership of the AES to the Aboriginal community and the appointment of Cathy Duncan, a young tenacious Aboriginal educator, as Chair of the AES. Together Cathy and Dick begin to inspire change in the town of Moree, bringing a new hope of reconciliation between blacks and whites, increased employment for Aboriginals and a more positive attitude and respect between the two cultures. The partnership between Dick and Cathy is an interesting one with suspicion slowly turning into trust, ignorance into understanding, despair into hope and eventually, through compromise, mutual respect and admiration for each other as they strive towards a common goal. An extraordinary story of a small community committed to change. Contains archival footage, some scenes in b&w. For more information see “www.abc.net.au/message/tv/docos/moree/”

results.title: Inside the square [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Jaya Balendra and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: This is the story of two unknown London-based architects and their journey as winners in an international design competition in 1997, held by the then Premier of Victoria, Jeff Kennett, to create a bold new civic and cultural centre for Melbourne. Unlike the Sydney Opera House which was a single entity, Federation Square was more about a multitude of uses - restaurants, cinemas, bars, public spaces and a last minute addition, the National Gallery of Victoria. In 1998, Don Bates and Peter Davidson of Lab Architecture Studio teamed up with local based firm Bates Smart on a project of such magnitude, controversy and conflict that it took six years and more than 5000 people to complete. The program follows the final year of construction in the lead up to the opening of Federation Square and contains interviews with many of those involved including Don Bates, Peter Davidson, Dimity Reed (Architecture writer and critic), Peter Seamer (CEO, Federation Square Management), Tony Cosma (Project Manager, Multiplex), and Stan Liacos (Marketing Manager, Federation Square Management). The radical design of the buildings caused constant conflict and dispute between the architects and the builders, likewise with the builders and sub-contractors and the fact that the project was started before the architects had even finished their designs also created major problems from budget blow-outs, revisions in design to compromise and extended delays in completion. A documentary presenting the human side of one of Australia’s biggest public projects since the Opera House. Narrated by Justin Murphy.

results.title: Early days yet: a profile of the poet Allen Curnow
results.creator_credit: Shirley Horrocks and Point of View Productions
results.brief_description: This is a beautifully presented documentary about the life and memories of the highly acclaimed New Zealand poet, critic and anthropologist, Allen Curnow. At the age of almost 90, Allen Curnow still wrote poetry using “a ball-point, quantities of A4 paper, and a typewriter”. Charming, gentle and retiring, family man and serious poet, Allen Curnow has won many awards in the world of literature including seven New Zealand Book Awards and the first person outside of Britain to receive the Queen’s Gold Medal for Poetry. The program features Curnow reading several of his poems accompanied by evocative and emotive images to illustrate his writings which often reflect memories of people, places or events from his past. With his quiet sense of humor and reminiscing, and through interviews with his wife Jenny, and fellow poets including Bill Manhire, C.K. Stead, Ian Wedde, Leigh Davis and Elizabeth Smither, Allen Curnow allows us a glimpse into both his personal and his creative life. The documentary takes its title from his latest publication “Early days yet: new and collected poems 1941-1997”. Sadly Allen Curnow passed away on 23 September 2001, three months after completion of this film. Contains archival footage and some scenes in b&w.

results.title: Paying for the past [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Nicola Woolmington, Penny Robins, SBS Independent, Film Victoria and Annamax Media
results.brief_description: An intriguing documentary which follows the story of a group of lawyers from Germany, United States and Australia who are in the process of negotiating the biggest class action the world has ever seen. Acting on behalf of Holocaust survivors who were either used as forced labour or slave labour for the German industrialists such as Siemens, BMW and Krupp, during World War II, these lawyers are seeking to put closure on Germany’s dark past through financial compensation, and emotional and moral reparation. Forced and slave labourers worked under the most horrendous conditions and came from the concentration camps, consisting of gypsies, homosexuals and Jews. BMW had upto 20,000 slave labourers by 1944, many who did not survive. Whereas forced labourers were never intended to be killed off, slave labourers were part of a German “destruction through work” policy, for example, at Krupp’s, eight out of ten slave labourers died. Australia, with the highest Holocaust survivor population after Israel, has over 3000 claimants with Henry Burstyner, a tenacious and unrelenting Melbourne lawyer, representing Australia in the class action. Includes personal narratives from Kitia Altman, Abraham Biderman and Erica Turek, Holocaust survivors in Melbourne and Sydney, along with family photographs, stills and archival footage and appearances by Karen Heilig (Claims Conference, NY), Kenneth McCallion (Goodkind Firm), Dr Michael Witti (Germany), Ed Fagan (Fagan & D’Avino, US) and Henry Burstyner in their negotiations with the German companies - their aim: settlement by the end of the millenium. Narrated by Robert Menzies.

results.title: I witness: the art of George Gittoes (D)
results.creator_credit: Don Featherstone, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Featherstone Productions
results.brief_description: Australian artist, photographer and writer George Gittoes reflects the darker side of human nature in his paintings, the evil side which many artists are unwilling to acknowledge or address. In his own words “the story is more important than the drawing”. A deeply religious and spiritual person Gittoes has traversed the world and all its horrific wars including Rwanda, Bosnia, Vietnam, Northern Ireland and the Middle East. He admits he is not interested in national boundaries only that he is totally passionate in his hatred of human violence and war. This revealing and often confronting documentary follows his journey to China during the 1998 floods where we see him as a street artist capturing the lives of ordinary Chinese citizens as they go about their daily lives; travelling down the great Yangtze River to the construction site of the Three Gorges Dam; and at work in his Beijing studio. Throughout the film which is interspersed with images of a variety of his works, Gittoes talks about his life, his family, his philosophy on humanity and the stories behind each of the paintings portrayed in this program. This is one artist who is not afraid to push the boundaries. NB: CONTAINS SEVERAL DISTURBING IMAGES OF WAR AND ITS VICTIMS.

results.title: Conversations with a dead poet: Alan Wearne recalls John Forbes [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Geoff Burton, John Izzard, Seedwillow and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: Alan Wearne, poet and tutor hosts this documentary about his friend and colleague John Forbes (1950-98), one of Australia’s most prominent modern poets with his distinctly gritty writing about urban Melbourne and Sydney. Drawing on extracts from several of Forbes’ poems, and discussions with friends and devotees of his writing, the following works are explored in detail: “Tropical skiing”; “On the beach”; “Stalin’s holidays”; “The Stunned mullet”; “Damaged glamour”.
results.title_for_label: Conversations with a dead poet: Alan Wearne recalls John Forbes [Widescreen]

results.title: Die Deutschen luftwaffe. No. 6. Bombers & bomber ops 1942-1945
results.creator_credit: Mickey Shephard, Mike Croker and VAF Productions
results.brief_description: This documentary video contains some rare archival footage of the German Luftwaffe carrying out some of their bombing operations during the years 1942-1945 of World War II including photo-intelligence surveillance, aerial bombings, strikes on allied convoys with anti-ship missiles and night bomber raids against the British. At one stage during 1942, the Luftwaffe were capable of launching up to 1000 sorties per day. However by 1944 due to the growing effectiveness of Allied air power, the Luftwaffe bombing force began to decline, until Germany’s eventual surrender in May 1945. Aeroplane enthusiasts, and particularly those into war planes, will enjoy this documentary for its informative and historical visuals and its coverage of the various bombers used by the Luftwaffe, including the Junkers Ju-88 and Ju-188, the Dornier 217 series and the Heinkel He-111 and He-177, as well as flying boats and float planes operating from the Mediterranean through to the Arctic Ocean (in rare colour footage). Narrated by Brian Matthews.

results.title: Glimpses of Australia. [No. 02?]
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items include: 1. A lesson in geography - shows the size of Australia in relation to Scandinavia and Europe. 2. Warburton District - located on the Great Dividing Range, Victoria, shows scenery and inhabitants. 3. The Princes Highway - from Lakes Entrance to Narooma inlet. Shows Lakes Entrance locals and holiday-makers; an Aborigine fishing with a spear; Narooma’s beautiful inlet; oyster fishing and eating. 4. Animal bandits - animals dance to the sound of birds; they form a band but their tunes are unbearable until they attend Professor Heron’s school of music.

description_for_label: Cinemagazine items include: 1. A lesson in geography - shows the size of Australia in relation to Scandinavia and Europe. 2. Warburton District - located on the Great Dividing Range, Victoria, shows scenery and inhabitants. 3. The Princes Highway - from Lakes Entrance to Narooma inlet. Shows Lakes Entrance locals and holiday-makers; an Aborigine fishing with a spear; Narooma’s beautiful inlet; oyster fishing and eating. 4. Animal bandits - animals dance to the sound of birds; they form a band but their tunes are unbearable until they attend Professor Heron’s school of music.

results.title: [Kodak Cinegraph compilation. No. 05]
results.brief_description: A compilation of silent newsreels including: 1. Coronation of (probably) King George V. 2. The tribute of the forest - The ‘Hoop Pine’ of Queensland used for making matches and butter boxes. An example of the “winch and steel cable” method (?) - logging in Queensland. Bullock teams also shown hauling logs. 3. Burton Holmes’ Film Reels of Travel - alpine vistas. 4. Alfred Weiss presents ‘Another kick coming’. 5. Sheep dipping and general farm scenes. 6. Granite Quarry in action. 7. Steel production.

results.title: Autumn: a concept film
results.brief_description: A short experimental film which focuses on one tree as it loses its leaves during the autumn season. We watch until finally the last leaf falls and the tree is completely bare. Without commentary but accompanied with music. No other credits available.
